content: Career Asked by AnonymousAsked on 15 Mar 2019I accepted a job offer 3 days ago by an MNC. But then I just received a much better one today. What is the right thing to do?Second company offered me about 20% higher pay with OT, closer to home, and more employee benefits, but might be a dwindling business.3 answersAnswerBump0

Junus EuTop Contributor (Sep)Level 8. WizardUpdated on 18 Jul 2019Personally for me I would still go with the MNC because:Integrity. I had already accepted - and it's not the best thing to go back on my word.Like you mention, second company might be a dwindling business That said, of course the 20% higher pay is enticing, but with OT - what does that mean? If you are eventually going to work 30% extra time, would that 20% higher pay still be interesting to you?I would also consider the job expansion prospects in both companies. See if you are able to grow in that role, and what are the opportunities they could offer.0 comments4

WonderkidAnswered on 15 Mar 2019Unfortunately without the benefit of hindsight, there is no absolute right thing to do.Assuming a usual median salary (so the 20% works out to about $800 a month), that you are young and that this is one of your first few jobs in the chosen career,  I would ignore the pay and benefits for now, and focus more on how the 2 companies can impact on your potential career path. This will mean, among others, consideration of the skills you are likely to learn, what you would think you would like to do, the industry you will be gaining exposure to and what your potential next promotion / move to another company will be.If the decision is to take the better offer, please deal with the MNC nicely and professionally. There is unlikely to be any legal repercussion on you breaking the employment contract since you have not started work, but they might be less receptive if you ever need to work with/for them again in future.0 comments2
